newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel rules out higher new borrowing in 1998.
newsitem.headline: Waigel rules out higher new borrowing in 1998.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel ruled out increasing government new debt in 1998, saying total borrowing in the year must remain under 58 to 59 billion marks.

Speaking to reporters, Waigel said meeting borrowing rules next year mandated by the German constitution would be more difficult than meeting stability criteria required for European economic and monetary union (EMU).
The German constitution requires that new government borrowing does not exceed total public investment.
Waigel said he expected public investment in 1998 of around 58 to 59 billion marks, a figure similar to this year's. This meant there would be little room to increase government borrowing.
"We are standing before a very decisive four weeks," Waigel said of preparations for the 1998 budget.
The Finance Minister also called on his liberal coalition partners the Free Democrats (FDP) to take a shared responsibility in seeing that the budget conformed to the constitution.
